physical_examinations.relevant_findings: The circumference of the right thigh was noticeably larger than that of the left. There were no overlying dermatologic changes, cellulitis, or fluctuant masses. There was a deep, well-circumscribed, firm mass on the medial aspect of the proximal part of the right thigh. Inguinal lymphadenopathy was not appreciable, and motor, sensory, and vascular testing was unremarkable. The Tinel test was negative.
The surgical incision healed uneventfully. The activity level of the patient was nearly normal, and he reported no symptoms of a systemic infection.
physical_examinations.changes_over_time: The patient initially had a deep-seated, painless mass that was indistinguishable from that expected of a soft-tissue sarcoma, which was successfully treated with surgical debridement and antifungal therapy.
The rapid resolution of the abscess after surgical decompression and antimicrobial therapy suggested effective management.
